The Lights button, available in the sidebar, will give you an overhead 
 view of the current design with the light showing relationship to where 
 it is currently placed. Simply select the Light in the view to set it's 
 Properties. The best thing to do with lighting is to experiment with it 
 to see what works best for you.
image1087.gif

The Automatic 
 lighting setup places at least the following two Lights in every Room:

The Sun Light, which is a directional 
	 light placed in the southwest corner of the scene. 
 The Center Light, which is a Point 
	 Light placed in the Center of the Scene.

The Sun Light, which is a directional 
	 light placed in the southwest corner of the scene.

The Center Light, which is a Point 
	 Light placed in the Center of the Scene.

The Center Light, which is a Point 
	 Light placed in the Center of the Scene.

You can modify the settings for any of these Automatic Lights and your 
 changes will be preserved. If you would like to have your own Light Schedule 
 for the Job you can click the New or Copy button in the toolbar.

To adjust a light, select it by clicking on it. It will be highlighted 
 with a dashed outline when it is selected. Now you can move it anywhere 
 in the view port or change any of the Light, Beam, or Direction specifications 
 available to that particular type of Light.

You can add or delete lights with the Add/Delete buttons and save different 
 lighting setups to the Light Schedule.
Light Properties
image1016.gif
Enabled
A light can be temporarily shut off by de-selecting the Enabled flag.
Color

The Color list lets you tint the light to simulate different types of 
 light sources, such as White Light (whitish), Sky Light (bluish), Sun 
 Light (yellowish), Fluorescent (greenish), or Incandescent (orangish). 
 You can just use White Light (the default setting for a new light), but 
 if you want to give your scene a little more color, try experimenting 
 with the other color settings. The more lights you set to a particular 
 color, the more pronounced that color will be.
Brightness

Brightness is your most important setting and controls the overall intensity 
 of the light.
Beam Properties
image1017.gif

The Beam Properties area will allow you to set up the type of light 
 beam that you will need for the effect you are looking for.
Type
There are three Light types:

Spot 
	 -  Appears as a red circle and projects a cone-like beam of 
	 light. 
 Directional 
	 -  Appears as a blue circle and projects a wide parallel beam 
	 of light as if from a distant source. 
 Point -  Appears as a light blue 
	 circle and acts as a ball of light projecting light in all directions. 
	 This is the most versatile or all light types.

Height

This setting allows you to set the Height 
 of a Spot or Point Light. Height is not an option for a Directional Light.
Angle

If you have the light set as a spotlight, 
 you will be able to control the angle of the light-cone it creates.  The 
 tighter the cone, the more intense the light will be and the stronger 
 the shadows.
Cast Shadows

Unlike the real world, it is possible to set whether a light casts shadows 
 or not.  Sometimes if you are just using a light to fill in a dark 
 part of a scene, you may not want that light to cast a distinct shadow. 
  The fewer lights casting shadows, the faster your scene will render.
Softness

This setting affects the sharpness of the spotlight cone and the shadows 
 that are cast.

In Ray-Trace rendering, if you have the Beam Softness set to zero and 
 you have the Ray-Trace Sharp Shadows flag turned on, then you will generate 
 a very sharp detailed shadow. In general, you will get more natural looking 
 lighting with the normal soft shadows.
Direction Properties
image167.gif

The Direction Properties 
 are not available for Point Lights.
Vertical

Allows you to set the Vertical Angle of your Light. You can also click 
 the action button in the Vertical field to get the Angle window. By grabbing 
 the "nose" of the light you can adjust its vertical angle.
image1018.gif

Once you get the light pointing in any direction, other than straight 
 down, it will also have a handle in the Light Editor which you can drag 
 to control where it is pointing.
Horizontal

Allows you to set the Vertical Angle of your Light. If your Light has 
 a Vertical Angle you can use the handle in the Light Viewport to rotate 
 the Light manually.

Geometry 
 Properties
image1088.gif

The Geometry Properties allow you to indicate if the Light Source is 
 actual physically visible. For Spot and Point Lights you establish the 
 Radius and for Directional Lights you establish its Width and Length.
Advanced Lighting

Lighting is the main thing you will need to spend time with in order 
 to use PhotoVision to its full potential. Before you continue into this 
 section, make sure you are familiar with the previous section on how to 
 select, move, and adjust light settings.

Sources of Inspiration

Look at magazines and pictures of rooms.  You may even want to 
 create a collection of rooms with different types of lighting situations. 
  Try to figure out the light sources in those pictures and practice 
 copying those effects in PhotoVision.  With a little bit of practice 
 you'll be amazed at how much your renderings will improve.
Types of Lights
Following are the types of lights you can use in your scene.
Spotlights

Spot Lights (red circle) cast a strong cone of light.  The narrower 
 the beam angle, the more intense the light and the more intense the shadow 
 it casts.  The angle of the beam ranges from 0 to 180 degrees.  A 
 setting of below 90 degrees casts a strong shadow while a setting of 180 
 casts virtually no shadow.  The Beam Softness setting affects the 
 softness of the shadows a spot light casts, as well as the fuzziness of 
 the spot light cone.  Spot lights are most useful to shine light 
 through windows or to simulate Can Lights or Lights flush to the Ceiling.
Directional Lights

Directional lights (blue circle) simulate light coming from a long distance 
 away.  It projects a wide parallel beam of light and, at high brightness 
 settings, casts a strong shadow. Though directional lights do not project 
 a cone of light, the Beam Softness setting does affect the softness of 
 the shadows it casts.  Use directional lights to fill large areas.

It does not matter where a directional light 
 is placed in the scene; only the direction it is pointing.  Even 
 if the directional light is in the Room, it will cast shadows as if it 
 is far outside the Room.  It also can't shine through walls.
Information.png
Point Lights

Point Lights (light blue circle) are the 
 most common form of artificial Lighting in the real world. It most accurately 
 simulates a light bulb as it casts light in all directions from its placement.
Lighting Setup
The following topics cover some basic lighting setups.
The "Center" Light

At the beginning of a Photovision project, you will start with a single 
 point light centered above your scene. If the light is too close to any 
 wall, move it out further so the light can better angle in toward the 
 fronts of your cabinets. A light in this position is referred to as a 
 "Center" light.
The "Key" Light

To give your rendering more contrast, it is a good idea to add another 
 light, in addition to the "Center" light, coming in from the 
 side.  This light is referred to as the "Key" light, or 
 primary light source in the scene.  The idea is to make one of your 
 walls brighter than the other. Usually the wall adjacent or opposite the 
 window is the brightest wall. The "Key" light is usually a spot 
 light positioned at ceiling height, angled slightly, and pointing primarily 
 toward one wall.
The "Fill" Light

Sometimes a third light is added to the scene. The "Fill" 
 light is usually positioned to fill in the areas of the scene not covered 
 by the "Key" light.  A directional light can serve well 
 as a "Fill" light. The "Fill" light is usually set 
 to a much lower brightness than the "Key" light.

The "Fill" light is usually placed at about half room height, 
 pointing sideways. Usually the higher the height of the "Key" 
 light, the lower the height of the "Fill" light.

Since much of the light in a kitchen is reflected light from walls and 
 floors, try to use the "Fill" light to simulate this effect. 
  For instance, you might tilt the "Fill" light slightly 
 upward to simulate light being reflected upward from the floor.  This 
 can lessen the severity of shadows under upper cabinets.  Good use 
 of a "Fill" light can add a subtle glow to cabinet faces and 
 lessen the flatness of the lighting in darker parts of the scene.
Window Light

A common addition to a kitchen lighting setup is a light shining through 
 a window. A window light is usually a spotlight set to cast shadows.  It's 
 beam angle is set so that it is just a little larger than the window frame. 
 For direct sunlight, the Beam Softness should be set very sharp, for indirect 
 sunlight set it softer.  You may want to set the color of the window 
 light to either sunlight or skylight.

The "Center" light inside the room (red circle) is usually 
 turned so that it is the pointing in the same general direction as the 
 window light.  The window light is used to cast bright light through 
 the window frame, but the "Center" light is still the primary 
 light source inside the room.
